title: How To Deal With A Partner Who's Always On Their Computer
summary: If you’re feeling jealous or resentful about the time your partner spends on the computer, try talking to them about it. It can be a good idea to sit down and talk to your partner about how much time they spend on their computer. If you both work full-time and have young children, you may want to come to an agreement about the amount of time they’ve spent on their computers. It’s important to spend time with your partner, but also important to make time for yourself as well.

intro.compiledSource:
const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:e,...t}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...t,components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,`When you enter into a relationship with another person, you\u2019ll naturally want to spend as much time together as possible. It can be super easy to fall into a routine when you\u2019re spending so much time with each other. You go to work, come home, and then retreat to your respective rooms for the rest of the night. And while that routine is totally normal and understandable at this stage in your relationship, it might not be exactly what you\u2019re looking for.
It\u2019s easy to get jealous or resentful if your partner is always on their computer \u2014 but that doesn\u2019t mean that there isn\u2019t a reason for their constant use of it. It could be that they are really passionate about something they\u2019re researching online or maybe they have an online business venture they\u2019ve been working on for a while now. However, if this is causing tension between you two, speak up! They may not even realize how much time they spend on their computer and just how much of an impact it has on your relationship. Here are some ways to deal with a partner who's always on their computer:`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

content.compiledSource:
const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:e,...t}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...t,components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("h2",null,"Communicate with your partner"),mdx("p",null,`Sometimes, feelings of resentment can be misdirected and lead to feelings of jealousy. If your partner just happened to be spending a lot of time on their computer, it could be that they\u2019re into something really interesting. They could also just be trying to catch up on some work they need to do since they\u2019ve been so busy.
If you\u2019re feeling jealous and are unsure of why your partner is always on the computer, try communicating with them. Ask them what they\u2019ve been up to and see if they\u2019re willing to open up to you.`),mdx("h2",null,"Go out without them"),mdx("p",null,`It\u2019s possible that your partner is just trying to catch up on work that they\u2019ve been putting off. If they\u2019ve been spending their nights on the computer and not with you, it could be that they\u2019re just trying to finish something off or get caught up on a project.
You can try going out without your partner. It doesn\u2019t have to be a date night or anything like that. Just see if you can spend some time together outside of the house.
If you\u2019re worried about your partner being upset that you went out without them, it can be a good idea to be upfront and honest with them. Tell them that you want some time with them and see if they\u2019re willing to take a night off.`),mdx("h2",null,"Set boundaries and make agreements"),mdx("p",null,`It can be a good idea to sit down and talk to your partner about how much time they spend on their computer.
You can set boundaries with your partner. For example, if you both work full-time and have young children, you may want to come to an agreement about how much time they spend on their computer. It can be easy to get lost in the world of technology and lose track of time, so this can be a helpful way to avoid resentment and misunderstandings.`),mdx("h2",null,"Try resolving the issue together"),mdx("p",null,"If you and your partner are open and honest with each other, you may be able to resolve the issue and come up with a solution together."),mdx("p",null,"If you\u2019re feeling jealous or resentful about the time your partner spends on the computer, try talking to them about it. You may be able to resolve the issue and find a solution. Alternatively, you could also try asking them for help with something you\u2019re working on as well. Perhaps you have a project that\u2019s due soon or you need advice on something. If your partner is always on the computer, they may be able to help you out."),mdx("h2",null,"Break up if it doesn\u2019t work out"),mdx("p",null,"It\u2019s never easy to break up with a partner, but it may be necessary if the two of you just aren\u2019t a good fit. This can especially be the case if one of you always spends time on their computer to the detriment of the relationship between you two."),mdx("p",null,"If you\u2019ve tried to talk to your partner about how much time they spend on their computer and it\u2019s not working out, it might be time to break up with them."),mdx("p",null,"You don\u2019t want to be in a relationship that causes you pain and stress. You deserve to be happy and have a partner who makes you feel good about yourself. If your partner is always on the computer to the detriment of your relationship, you may need to say goodbye."),mdx("h2",null,"Conclusion"),mdx("p",null,"Your partner may just be interested in different things than you are. And that\u2019s okay! As long as they\u2019re not spending all of their time on their computer and ignoring you, there\u2019s no reason to get jealous or upset about it."),mdx("p",null,"However, it can be good for a relationship to have some balance. It\u2019s important to spend time with your partner, but it\u2019s also important to make time for yourself as well. It can be easy to get lost in a relationship, so make sure to set aside some time for yourself each day."))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

relatedArticles.title: How to Make a Long-Distance Relationship Work
How to Get Out of a Style Rut

intro.compiledSource: const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:e,...t}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...t,components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,"The risk of falling into a style rut is something we all have to deal with from time to time. It happens to even the most confident and daring of people, so you\u2019re certainly not alone if you feel like your style is stagnating and you can\u2019t think of anything new or exciting to wear. Whether it\u2019s because you haven\u2019t found a new piece of clothing that excites you in months, or because you just don\u2019t know what to wear after wearing variations on the same theme for several weeks in a row, everyone gets stuck in a rut now and again. Thankfully there are ways to get out of it and discover a new lease on your personal style once again."))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

relatedArticles.title: 5 Ways to Cut down on Screen Time
10 Easy Tips for Sticking to Your New Year's Resolutions

intro.compiledSource: const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:e,...t}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...t,components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,"New Year\u2019s resolutions are like a clean slate for the coming year. What you do with that opportunity is up to you. Maybe you resolve to eat healthier, exercise more or reduce stress and anxiety. Maybe you decide to learn a new skill, read more books, help others or travel more. Or maybe your resolution is to do something completely different \u2014 like learn a language, stop procrastinating or read the complete works of Shakespeare. The possibilities are endless, but sticking to those resolutions can be challenging. The key is establishing habits that will last all 365 days of the year and not just one crazy day in January. It takes small but deliberate changes in everyday life that add up over time and become second nature. Here are 10 easy tips for sticking to your New Year\u2019s resolutions:"))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

relatedArticles.title: The Ultimate Guide to Spring Cleaning Your Home

intro.compiledSource:
const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:e,...t}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...t,components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,`Home cleaning in spring is the best time to thoroughly clean your home. As the weather gets warmer, so does our house. Dirt and grime that has accumulated over the long winter months begins to dissipate as we put away all of our heavy coats, hats, and gloves. With fewer layers to trap it, dust, germs, and other nasty particles are exposed for what they really are: gross!
We all know that a tidy home is a happy one. Keeping a tidy household at all times can be challenging. The pressures of work and other responsibilities often get in the way of keeping things clean and organized. But with some preparation and planning you can make spring home cleaning your primary focus instead of an afterthought. Here\u2019s how\u2026`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

relatedArticles.title: 50 Ways to Keep the Spark Alive in Your Relationship
How to Make Your Resolution to Get Fit a Reality
How to Deal with a Partner Who's Always Travelling
How to Deal with a Partner Who's Always Working

intro.compiledSource:
const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:e,...o}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...o,components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,`Working too much is a problem many people struggle with \u2014 but it\u2019s even more challenging when you\u2019re in a relationship with someone who has the same work ethic. If your partner usually leaves for work before you even get out of bed, or isn\u2019t home until after you\u2019re already in bed, things can get tricky.
Working from home, flexible hours and remote working are all buzzwords in today\u2019s labor market. Companies are becoming increasingly aware that it isn\u2019t just about how much time employees spend at the desk but also about what they achieve during that time. A Gallup poll found that telecommuting or working from home is growing in popularity among professionals across most industries. Working remotely makes it easier to find jobs, negotiate schedules and live without a commute.`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

relatedArticles.title: 5 Ways to Make Your Mornings Easier

intro.compiledSource:
const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:e,...o}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...o,components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,`You know those people who seem to get out of bed with ease every morning? You know, the people that you see on Instagram and wonder how they\u2019re so happy so early in the day? Well, we hate to break it to you but those people have their own set of problems. Getting up after a long night is hard for them too; the only difference is that their solutions work.
These people have their own rituals and habits when it comes to waking up in the morning. If these folks can do it then why can\u2019t we? It\u2019s because some of us are too comfortable, which means we need to shake things up! Do you want to be one of those people who gets out of bed with ease and has a productive day ahead of them? In this blog post, we\u2019ll tell you 5 ways you can make your mornings easier.`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;
